intro: Melandrium wrightii, commonly known as Wright's catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its delicate, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and has hairy stems and leaves. Its scientific name honors the botanist John Wright, who contributed significantly to the study of North American flora. Wright's catchfly is an important species for ecological studies due to its unique adaptations to arid environments.
